title: The World’s Best Player Without a Position
sub_head: France midfielder N’Golo Kanté has defied soccer orthodoxy to become one of the most influential players in the game
body:
SURESNES, France—In the days before French midfielder N’Golo Kanté dominated World Cup matches and Champions League finals, his youth coach would drive him around the Paris suburbs trying to show off a subtle, yet crucial point about his game.
Kanté looks small, he would tell bigger clubs on the hunt for talent, but believe me, he’s not too small to be useful. It was a tough case to make considering Kanté is 5-foot-6 on a good day.
“Today he’s listed at 5-6,” said Pierre Ville, the former technical director here at JS Suresnes. “I’m not convinced he’s even that tall.”
A decade later, Kanté hasn’t grown, but his stature in world soccer is enormous and he is a key part of France’s bid to win the European Championship this summer.
At 30, he has won almost every other piece of hardware available: the World Cup, the Premier League, the FA Cup, the Europa League, and the Champions League. He was an essential piece of Leicester City’s 5,000-to-1 run to the English title in 2016. And last month, he was voted man of the match as Chelsea became European club champion.
